docs.snippet: On Wednesday, Zambia and Ivory Coast advanced to Sunday's final of the Africa Cup of Nations.
docs.lead_paragraph: Zambia, which saw most of its national team players killed in a plane crash in 1993, then advanced to the final of the 1994 Africa Cup of Nations, upset favored Ghana Wednesday to advance to this year's final.
docs.abstract: On Wednesday, Zambia and Ivory Coast advanced to Sunday's final of the Africa Cup of Nations.

headline.main: Africa Cup of Nations: Zambia and Ivory Coast in Final

docs.snippet: Decriminalizing personal drug use in Argentina would be a long-overdue corrective to drug-control policies that have failed.
docs.abstract: Decriminalizing personal drug use in Argentina would be a long-overdue corrective to drug-control policies that have failed.

docs.snippet: Decriminalizing personal drug use in Argentina would be a long-overdue corrective to drug-control policies that have been an utter failure.
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES - "When we first started, no one would consider advertising with us," says Sebastián Basalo, the founder of THC, a magazine devoted to marijuana and its fans. (THC is the main psychoactive agent in the cannabis plant.) "Now we even get some big companies once in a while."
docs.abstract: Decriminalizing personal drug use in Argentina would be a long-overdue corrective to drug-control policies that have been an utter failure.

docs.snippet: Recent events on British soccer fields raise questions of race and identity many decades after the country transformed from a largely white society to one that is more ethnically diverse.
docs.lead_paragraph: Recent events on British soccer fields raise questions of race and identity many decades after the country transformed from a largely white society to one that is more ethnically diverse.
docs.abstract: Memo from Britain; occasional use of racist slurs on British soccer fields raises questions of race and identity many decades after the country transformed from a largely white society to one more ethnically diverse; what makes images of hatred and discrimination in soccer, sport which commentators say is built into the urban psyche, so compelling is that Britain seemed to be emerging from its racial shadows.

headline.main: In Britain, Soccer Holds Up an Uncomfortable Mirror
headline.print_headline: Soccer Holds Up an Uncomfortable Mirror

docs.snippet: Mrs. Fortabat married a cement tycoon, expanded his empire after his death and became an art collector and philanthropist as well as the richest woman in Argentina.
docs.lead_paragraph: Mrs. Fortabat married a cement tycoon, expanded his empire after his death and became an art collector and philanthropist as well as the richest woman in Argentina.
docs.abstract: Amalia Lacroze de Fortabat, major Argentine art collector and philanthropist, dies at age 90.

headline.seo: Amalia de Fortabat, 90, Dies; Noted for Art and Scandal
headline.main: Amalia de Fortabat, 90, Dies; Noted for Art and Scandal
headline.print_headline: Amalia de Fortabat, 90, Dies; Noted for Art and Scandal

docs.snippet: LONDON -- Britons sometimes celebrate sports as a metaphor for life itself, from the possibly apocryphal assertion by the Duke of Wellington that the battle of Waterloo was won on the playing fields of Eton to the pepperings of cricket in political...
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Britons sometimes celebrate sports as a metaphor for life itself, from the possibly apocryphal assertion by the Duke of Wellington that the battle of Waterloo was won on the playing fields of Eton to the pepperings of cricket in political analysis: a politician ''on the back foot'' is, usually, deemed to be on the defensive; the front foot denotes muscular attack. But, if those comparisons bear scrutiny, then events on the nation's soccer pitches in recent times offer a more painful conclusion, conjuring questions of race and identity many decades after Britain embarked on a long and tortured transformation from a largely white society to one in which ethnic diversity has come to claim an ambiguous position, somewhere between a commonplace and a stubborn source of contention, hatred and even violence.
docs.abstract: Memo from Britain; occasional use of racist slurs on British soccer fields raises questions of race and identity many decades after the country transformed from a largely white society to one more ethnically diverse; what makes images of hatred and discrimination in soccer, sport which commentators say is built into the urban psyche, so compelling is that Britain seemed to be emerging from its racial shadows. Photo (M)

headline.main: Soccer Holds Up an Uncomfortable Mirror

docs.snippet: A Honduran fire and a Mexican massacre have drawn new attention to dangerous conditions in Latin American prisons, which have outlasted scrutiny before.
docs.lead_paragraph: A Honduran fire and a Mexican massacre have drawn new attention to dangerous conditions in Latin American prisons, which have outlasted scrutiny before.
docs.abstract: Grisly prison fire that killed 360 inmates in Honduras and a massacre in a prison in Mexico that left 44 inmates dead have drawn new attention to dangerous conditions in Latin American prisons; prison administrators and investigators are warning that the problem has sunk to new depths, spurred by the growing power of criminal groups and the mounting demand to stop them.

headline.seo: In Latin America, Prisons Condemned to Crisis
headline.main: Inmate’s Lament: ‘Rather Be Dead Than Here’
headline.print_headline: Inmate’s Lament: ‘Rather Be Dead Than Here’

byline.contributor: Randal C. Archibold reported from El Salvador, Mexico and Guatemala. Reporting was contributed by Javier C. Hernández from San Pedro Sula, Honduras; William Neuman and María Eugenia Díaz from Caracas, Venezuela; Gene Palumbo from San Salvador; and Jenny Carolina González from Bogotá, Colombia.

docs.snippet: The American-led push over the Sri Lankan civil war has prompted a dispute at the United Nations Human Rights Council and fury in Sri Lanka.
docs.lead_paragraph: The American-led push over the Sri Lankan civil war has prompted a dispute at the United Nations Human Rights Council and fury in Sri Lanka.
docs.abstract: American-led initiative at the United Nations Human Rights Council calls on Sri Lanka to account for the carnage and possible war crimes that ended its civil war against the Tamil Tiger insurgency in 2011; Sri Lankan government reacts angrily, calling initiative 'divisive and polarizing'.

headline.main: Move at U.N. on Carnage in Sri Lanka Sets Off Fury
headline.print_headline: Move at U.N. On Carnage In Sri Lanka Sets Off Fury
